Lin et al. tests

Martin R. Smith martin.smith@durham.ac.uk

2020-02-11

Source: vignettes/Lin.Rmd
Lin.Rmd

Distance measurements can be used to identify clusters of similar trees. I used three approaches to generate clusters of similar trees, and tested each metric in its ability to recover these clusters [@Lin2012].

For the first test, I generated 500 datasets of 50 binary trees with n = 40 leaves. Each set of trees was created by uniformly sampling two k-leaf ‘skeleton’ trees, where k ranges from 0.3 n to 0.9 n. From each skeleton, 50 trees were generated by adding each of the remaining n – k leaves at a uniformly selected point on the tree.

Ranking: rank for each value of k and each clustering method, using lowest value in ties. Then average across all values of k and all clustering methods for each test.

Test one Test two Test three Mean rank
JRF (k=2, arboreal) 6.16 6.425 2.52 5.04
Diff. Phylog. Info 5.64 4.325 6.74 5.57
Clust. Info. Dist. 3.98 10.250 5.70 6.64
JRF (k=2, non-arb.) 4.64 12.850 2.50 6.66
paste(plain(“Nye”), italic(“et al.”)) 4.00 13.575 3.14 6.90
JRF (k=4, arboreal) 8.50 7.125 5.58 7.07
JRF (k=4, non-arb.) 7.12 10.475 4.68 7.42
Match. Split Info Dist 4.22 12.200 9.06 8.49
TBR (ub approx.) 10.86 5.450 10.24 8.85
TBR (lb approx.) 11.16 4.900 12.14 9.40
NNI (upr bnd) 12.36 7.025 10.62 10.00
NNI (lwr bnd) 13.00 6.875 11.12 10.33
Robinson-Foulds 13.00 6.925 11.18 10.37
SPR (approx.) 11.40 8.350 12.44 10.73
Match. Split Dist. 6.46 13.050 13.70 11.07
Path 13.50 6.200 14.64 11.45
